race.name: Paris Mountain Gravel Grinder
race.tagline: South Carolina Paris Mountain gravel in Travelers Rest.

climate.description: Variable conditions with heat and humidity possible.

terrain.surface: Gravel roads through Paris Mountain area. Significant elevation with mountain scenery.

gravel_god_rating.score_note: Regional SC event. Paris Mountain terrain is nice but moderate organization and regional field.

biased_opinion.verdict: Upstate SC Paris Mountain Regional Gravel
biased_opinion.summary: Paris Mountain Gravel Grinder is a regional event in Travelers Rest near Greenville. The Paris Mountain terrain offers significant climbing with mountain scenery, and the proximity to Greenville provides excellent access. However, the moderate organization and regional field keep it firmly in Tier 3. It's a solid regional event for South Carolina cyclists.
biased_opinion.bottom_line: A solid regional South Carolina gravel race with Paris Mountain terrain. Worth it for SC cyclists seeking a local mountain event. Not a destination race for out-of-state travelers.

final_verdict.one_liner: South Carolina Paris Mountain gravel in Travelers Rest.
final_verdict.should_you_race: If you're in South Carolina and want a local Paris Mountain gravel event—yes, it's a solid regional race. If you're from out of state—there are better options.
final_verdict.alternatives: For better Southeast events: Cohutta, Southern Cross. For similar regional events: other SC gravel races.

logistics.lodging_strategy: Travelers Rest and Greenville have lodging options.

course_description.character: Paris Mountain gravel with significant climbing.
course_description.signature_challenge: Paris Mountain climbing in upstate South Carolina.

non_negotiables.why: Paris Mountain requires solid climbing fitness (5000 feet).
SC spring/fall means heat and humidity are possible.

topics.heat: Racing in SC heat and humidity

marketplace_variables.race_hook: South Carolina Paris Mountain gravel in Travelers Rest.
marketplace_variables.race_hook_detail: Regional event with significant climbing near Greenville.

logistics.explanation: Travelers Rest location provides easy highway access from multiple directions, reasonable proximity to Greenville-Spartanburg airport. Small town logistics usually mean simple parking, straightforward packet pickup, none of the urban race chaos.

length.explanation: 65 miles hits the sweet spot for weekend warriors - long enough to matter, short enough to finish before dark. Not the suffer-fest distance that separates pretenders from contenders, but respectable middle ground. Similar distance to Crusher in the Tushar.

technicality.explanation: Paris Mountain features two distinct climbing approaches - Old Buncome at 2.17 miles and State Park Road at 3.69 miles. The terrain offers "two steep pitches" with grades reaching 10% at the summit and "a few switch backs" on the descent. Similar technical demands to Gravel Worlds.

elevation.explanation: 5000 feet over 65 miles delivers serious climbing at 77 feet per mile. Paris Mountain alone gains 1,565 feet from Old Buncome side, with the climb averaging "6% but there are only two steep pitches" including a final 10% grade to the summit. More climbing than SBT GRVL at the same score.

climate.explanation: South Carolina humidity turns any effort into a sweat lodge experience. Summer heat makes racing miserable, winter brings unpredictable ice storms, spring delivers pollen apocalypse. More weather exposure than Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.

altitude.explanation: Paris Mountain starts at 1,168 feet on Old Buncome side and tops out at 1,972 feet - minimal altitude with zero physiological impact. You'll get more altitude driving to the race than racing it. Lower altitude than Gravel Worlds — no thin-air concerns.

adventure.explanation: The 5.8-mile Paris Mountain traverse offers backcountry feel with safe descending practice. A blogger notes the summit reward: "Aside from a written statement 'You made it' on the top of the climb, there's no view to enjoy."

prestige.explanation: This race barely registers on the gravel radar - no search results, no race reports, no pro field mentions. When a 65-mile grinder in South Carolina can't even get a Wikipedia stub or a single race recap online, you're dealing with pure local theater. The gravel community talks about everything, so radio silence means irrelevance.

race_quality.explanation: Course utilizes quality infrastructure with "recently paved" roads described as "excellent" and "very smooth." However, race organization details and execution standards remain undocumented in available sources.

experience.explanation: 5000 feet of climbing over 65 miles around Travelers Rest suggests you'll get your money's worth of suffering. Paris Mountain State Park terrain means real climbs and actual gravel, not rail-trail nonsense. The experience exists - finding information about it apparently doesn't.

community.explanation: South Carolina gravel scene keeps events intimate and local-focused, which builds tight communities among the dozen people who show up. Travelers Rest sits in cycling-friendly Greenville metro area, so the bones for good community exist. Small fields create bonds - if they create anything at all.

field_depth.explanation: Greenville attracts strong cyclists to Paris Mountain as a go-to training climb (6% average grade, 10% at the top), but the gravel grinder draws from local riders rather than traveling specialists. The Swamp Rabbit Trail cycling corridor near Furman University provides a deep recreational base, though the competitive field stays regional without attracting dedicated gravel racers from outside the Upstate area. Less competitive depth than Almanzo 100.

value.explanation: Can't find registration fees, but South Carolina races typically run $60-80 for this distance. 5000 feet of climbing delivers challenge per dollar, assuming the race actually happens. Value depends on execution you can't research in advance.

expenses.explanation: Registration runs $60-100. Travelers Rest keeps costs reasonable without Asheville tourist pricing or Atlanta metro expense. Greenville area offers decent lodging options without breaking budgets, supported by established cycling tourism infrastructure. Similar expense level to Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.

a man riding a bike down a street at sunset

primary.name: Specialized Pathfinder Pro
primary.why: Fast center, grippy edges. The modern all-rounder benchmark.

primary.name: IRC Boken Double Cross
primary.why: Underrated mixed-terrain tire. Fast center with confident shoulder grip.

primary.name: Panaracer GravelKing SK
primary.why: Affordable all-rounder. Light knobs add grip without killing speed.

front_rear_split.rationale: Faster front for reduced rolling resistance on straights, grippier rear for traction on loose climbs and corners

videos.title: Gravel Ride: South Carolina Mountains
videos.description: 50 miles of back roads and gravel in the South Carolina Blue Ridge Mountains.   Started and finished at Oconee State Park in Mountain Rest, SC.

videos.title: Hotel Domestique Cycling, Travelers Rest, SC
112mi/180km Gravel Route only had 1 REST STOP (Eroica: Heroic Route)
videos.description:
Cycle Central Coast helps people find good cycling routes on the Central Coast of California. They also helped our family during the evacuation shuffle so myself and few bros went out and test rode the Eroica: Heroic Route. 

The problem with this cycling route though, was that it was designed for a Fondo, where each winery had rest stops. But in Vegan Cyclist fashion, we just sent it and hoped for the best.

We only had one rest stop on this cycling adventure , which was actually a detour, but what an amazing route. You can check other routes at www.cyclecentralcoast.com or follow my strava (https://www.strava.com/activities/4056700794) but beware that our route had literally ZERO stops, we had to detour to find one.  

0:00 Talking Head
2:08 Ride Starts
4:50 Gravel Climb
7:56 Rider Bio
9:55 Finding Food
12:34 Family Stuff

If you want to see the daily vlogging of the evacuation shuffle, check out my Instagram Highlights here, there's 7 different highlights. 
P1 https://www.instagram.com/stories/highlights/17850383765321954/
P2 https://www.instagram.com/stories/highlights/17928348784429478/

videos.title: LONDON-PARIS Gravel 2024 Entries Now Open | Hotchillee
videos.description:
Ride gravel all the way from the Thames to the Seine, finishing at the foot of the iconic Eiffel Tower. 

This is a fully supported Hotchillee event, so you’ll be looked after by a dedicated events team of mechanics, sports therapists, Ride Captains and logistics crew with over 20 years experience. You ride your bike... we do the rest.

Over three stunning days in the saddle, you'll ride a route almost entirely off-road with the final leg to Paris designed by Sofiane Sehilli. Cruise over broad meadows, wind along towpaths, country lanes, and tackle challenging single track. Choose to ride on your own or in a group with the Hotchillee Ride Captains leading the way - it's your call.

We carry your bags to keep you bike light, and you'll stay in 3* and 4* hotels along the way. We offer a well-earned sports massage at the end of each stage too. Return to the UK by Eurostar is included as well as secure bike transport back to Surrey.

More Information and book: https://www.hotchillee.com/events/london-paris-gravel/

-----------------------------

Join the Hotchillee Community on the Hotchillee App - https://www.hotchillee.com/hotchillee-app-update/

Instagram - https://www.instagram.com/hotchillee.cc/
Facebook - https://www.facebook.com/hotchillee/
Twitter - https://twitter.com/hotchillee

key_challenges.name: Santa Rosa Creek
key_challenges.description: The steep sections are extremely steep - you have to be fully out of the saddle and some riders walk portions. One rider's best time up this climb is 11 minutes.

terrain_notes.text: Santa Rita road gravel is smooth enough that you don't need a gravel bike - you can do it on a road bike no problem. The dirt surface is very manageable.

gear_mentions.text: IRC X Guards tires are recommended - rider hasn't flatted in three years with them. Tubeless setup is highly recommended once you get it dialed with the right tires.

race_day_tips.text: If you can only do one of the roads in the area - Santa Rosa's, Old Creek, or Santa Rita - Santa Rita is the way to go. It's quiet, beautiful, and you can descend the back side to Santa Margarita.

additional_quotes.text: We're gonna go for a big ride today we're gonna go about 107 miles. They're tied in with the tourism board and they've been huge finding dog friendly hotels but again there isn't availability like for a week or two so we're kind of been jumping from one place to another place.

rider_intel.search_text: Riders describe challenging climbs including Santa Rosa Creek, which features extremely steep sections requiring full out-of-saddle efforts with some riders walking portions. The area offers multiple climbing options including Old Creek and Santa Rita road. Santa Rita road is highlighted as gravel that's smooth enough for road bikes, described as quiet and beautiful with scenic views. The terrain around Santa Margarita offers varied surfaces from steep paved climbs to manageable gravel roads. Riders recommend tubeless tire setups and specifically mention IRC X Guards for reliability. The riding area features multiple santa-named roads with different character - some extremely challenging climbs and others more accessible gravel suitable for various bike types.
